incidents.name: Docker Hub Registry Timing Out: Fly Platform Impact

incident_updates.body:
The Docker Hub timing out issue has been marked resolved. 

https://www.dockerstatus.com/pages/incident/533c6539221ae15e3f000031/6515dbc89fabff05350ae18d

We updated our remote builders to load their images from docker-hub-mirror.fly.io/flyio/rchab, which is a caching mirror of registry-1.docker.io. We're seeing remote builders more reliably work.

Deployments that use an image from the Docker Hub Registry—any unqualified FROM in a Dockerfile or setting an unqualified image name with `fly deploy --image`—may still fail.

You can try adding docker-hub-mirror.fly.io/IMAGE_NAME to your Dockerfile or the `--image` flag on `fly deploy`. That will work more reliably if we have a cached copy of the image from Docker Hub.

The `fly deploy --local-only` work around is still a good option, if it works for you.

Another work around is finding another registry, like ghcr.io or quay.io or something like that, which has a copy of the image you would normally get from the Docker Hub Registry.

Marking this as monitoring while we wait for further updates from Docker Hub via their status page.

Docker Hub has an ongoing outage with their registry: https://www.dockerstatus.com/pages/incident/533c6539221ae15e3f000031/6515dbc89fabff05350ae18d

Deployments that use an image from the Docker Hub Registry—any unqualified FROM in a Dockerfile or setting an unqualified image name with `fly deploy --image`—may fail.

Existing machines and allocs are not affected. Creating apps, machines, or allocs from images in the Fly Registry (registry.fly.io/APP_NAME) are working.

Remote builders may fail to download the image from Docker Hub. We're working on a fix for that now.

Try `fly deploy --local-only` if you experience remote builder issues as result of this issue. That will use a local docker environment on your system to build and push the image. That might work and work around the remote builder issue for now, though we understand local docker environments can be unreliable in certain cases (for example, building linux/amd64 images on macOS M1/M2 chips can seqfault with a known wontfix issue in qemu).
Connectivity has been restored
One of our providers is experiencing connectivity issues in the 'bog' region. Engineers are on site and investigating the cause.

incidents.name: Image pulls and deploys timing out

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved
A fix for this issue has been deployed and we are monitoring things are working as expected.

We've received several reports of timeouts when using "fly deploy" and repeated attempts to pull images can be seen in the logs. The cause has been identified and a fix is in the works. As a workaround, try temporarily setting FLY_REGISTRY_HOST=registry2.fly.io prior to running "fly deploy".

The incident has been resolved and we're not seeing any further issues with the registry.

Around 14:00 UTC a litefs cluster that supports the registry began lagging due to too many open files on individual hosts. We resolved the open file issue and recovered the litefs cluster, which was completed around 14:45 UTC.

Between 14:00 and 14:45 UTC deployments may have failed to push images to the registry. This prevented machines and nomad allocs from getting updates, and did not interfere with existing machine & nomad alloc operation.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We're investigating issues with the registry failing to allow new images to be uploaded.

incidents.name: fly-metrics.net charts and prometheus cluster not responding

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

Our internal proxy service that marshals prometheus queries through our api was hitting hard limits with request and fly-proxy was not routing requests to the actual machines. Restarting the internal proxy service reset those limits and enabled prometheus queries to run successfully.

Our monitoring shows fly-metrics.net and https://fly.io/apps/YOUR_APP_NAME/metrics both working as expected now. We'll monitor the issue for a bit to ensure this doesn't regress.

Charts at https://fly-metrics.net/ are failing to load with error messages like this one:

server_error: server error: 503: details: <html><body><h1>503 Service Unavailable</h1> No server is available to handle this request. </body></html>

The https://fly.io/apps/YOUR_APP_NAME/metrics view is showing "No data available" for all charts, even when there should be data.

We are investigating a potential issue in our prometheus cluster that is causing both of those issues.

incidents.name: Deployments fail to load metadata from docker.io

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

We restarted our registry mirror that proxies requests to docker.io, and that cleared up the issue. Our metrics show deployments are working again. We'll continue to monitor for a bit to make sure this doesn't recur.

This issue impacted deployments that built images and required one or more images from docker.io. This impacted deployment between 2023-09-20 4:05 UTC and 7:40 UTC.

Deployments that build new images are failing with errors like:

ERROR [internal] load metadata for docker.io...

We're investigating the issue now.

The failed deployments do not impact existing machines and nomad allocs. They only prevent new changes from getting deployed.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.

A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

We've fixed the problem and are monitoring the results.
We found the problem and are working on a fix.
We're investigating intermittent deployment, dashboard and API access issues.
This incident has been resolved.
This issue has been mitigated, but we're still working on a more permanent fix.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.

We have a registry that only keeps storage in the iad region, which we think will work around the issue you are seeing. Try it out with:

FLY_REGISTRY_HOST=registry-iad.fly.io fly deploy

Use this if you are doing docker push directly to the registry:

FLY_REGISTRY_HOST=registry-iad.fly.io fly auth docker
docker push registry-iad.fly.io/torem-app:latest

We are working to fix the core issue. We'll report back once that's done. In the meantime, we hope the above unblocks deployments.
We are continuing to investigate the issue. In the meantime, customers can try deploys using registry2.fly.io.

App instances on affected hosts may have experienced intermittent interruptions in disk I/O, elevated network latency or request timeouts during this time.

Developers trying to create apps or machines, including during deployments, may have encountered “no capacity available in <region>" errors today. We deployed a change to flyd at 18:51 UTC and rolled it back at 19:25 UTC. That change included an occasional bug in how we calculate host capacity, which for some developers resulted in the "no capacity available in <region>" errors.

Please retry any deployments or machine creations that failed during this time.
Network has returned to normal operation
Connectivity should be improving. We are monitoring the situation.
There has been a large fiber cut in the JNB region that's affecting connectivity. We are working with our providers to route around the issue.

incidents.name: SIN network issues affected edges and wireguard gateways

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

An outage in SIN from an upstream network provider is causing issues with Wireguard gateways. If you are having trouble deploying or accessing your private network from a Wireguard peer in SIN, you'll likely need to temporarily create a peer in a different region.

Edges are affected as well, but traffic has been re-routed.

Between 14:30-16:15 UTC, a widespread Comcast/Xfinity network outage affected connectivity in several regions including `lax`, `bos`, `ewr`, and `atl`, causing network interruptions to applications and deployments in these regions. The issue seems to have been resolved.

incidents.name: Machines API degraded - returning 504s for a small number of requests

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue.
The Machines API (aka flaps) is returning 504 responses for a small number of requests. This may affect a small number of apps v2 deployments. Engineers are working to address the issue.
We have added a new region (BOM - Mumbai, India) to mitigate the capacity issues in MAA. At this time we suggest deploying workloads to BOM instead of MAA.

We are continuing to monitor the situation. 

Due to ongoing capacity constraints in MAA we recommend migrating your workloads to the alternative BOM region.

Your apps in MAA will continue to run, but it is no longer possible to create new Machines in this region.

Due to ongoing capacity constraints in MAA, we have built a new nearby region in BOM and recommend migrating your workloads there.

Your apps in MAA will continue to run, but it is no longer possible to create new Machines in this region.
We are currently working to add more capacity to MAA.
This incident has been resolved.
A fix has been deployed and we are monitoring the results.
